About

I am an early career data scientist with experience managing ecological data in a range of formats. In my personal research I pursued projects that allowed me to blend field, analytical, and modeling approaches to ask and answer community-level questions; this approach gave me first hand experience in both the tidying of raw data and the analysis and visualization of wrangled data.

The bulk of my coding experience is in R but I also have moderate competency with SQL and have self-taught R Shiny. I plan on learning more coding languages going forward as data challenges necessitate.

I firmly believe in transparency in data management and am an avid git user. Check out my GitHub profile for a selection of the public repositories that I own.

I am particularly proud of my work on the lterpalettefinder package, my personal ‘toolbox’ package helpR and the R Shiny data portal that I created for the Hebivory Variability Network. My code is well-commented and is meant to provide a clear window into the function and rationale of each operation.

In addition to data management, teaching and communicating scientific results are also things I love and hope to continue to focus on as my career develops. While a graduate student I sought out opportunities to teach and have guest lectured and taught labs in ecology, introductory biology, and multivariate analysis. I’ve developed R tutorials in an introduction to multivariate analysis, an introduction to random forest and best practices in quality control

Perhaps unsurprisingly for a data scientist such as myself but I am a huge Dungeons & Dragons fan and have begun working on a package (dndR) that serves any other people in the R / DnD Venn Diagram intersection.
